{{Infobox song | Name = The Heart Part 4 | Type = [[Promotional single]] | Cover = Kendrick-lamar-iv.png | Caption = | Alt = | Artist = [[Kendrick Lamar]] | Album = | Released = March 23, 2017 | Recorded = | Format = [[Music download|Digital download]] | Genre = {{hlist|[[Hip hop music|Hip hop]]}} | Length = {{Duration|m=4|s=48}} | Label = {{hlist|[[Aftermath Entertainment|Aftermath]]|[[Top Dawg Entertainment|Top Dawg]]|[[Interscope Records|Interscope]]}} | Producer = {{hlist|Syk Sense|Axlfolie|[[DJ Dahi]]|[[The Alchemist (musician)|The Alchemist]]{{cite web|url=http://2dopeboyz.com/2017/03/23/kendrick-lamar-the-heart-part-four-new-album-news/|title=Kendrick Lamar - The Heart Part 4|publisher=2DopeBoyz|accessdate=March 24, 2017}}}} | Writer = {{hlist|[[Kendrick Lamar|Kendrick Duckworth]]|Joshua Scruggs|Axel Morgan|[[DJ Dahi|Dacoury Natche]]|[[The Alchemist (musician)|Daniel Maman]]|[[Khalid (singer)|Khalid Robinson]]{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2017/03/who-produced-kendrick-lamar-heart-part-4/|title=Here's Who Produced Kendrick Lamar's "The Heart Part 4"|publisher=[[XXL (magazine)|XXL]]|accessdate=March 24, 2017}}}} }} "'''The Heart Part 4'''" is a song by American [[hip hop music|hip hop]] recording artist [[Kendrick Lamar]]. It was released on March 23, 2017, by [[Top Dawg Entertainment]]. The track features uncredited vocals from American singer [[Khalid (singer)|Khalid]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thefader.com/2017/03/24/kendrick-lamar-the-heart-part-4-khalid|title=Kendrick Lamar's "The Heart Part 4" Features An Uncredited Vocal From Khalid|publisher=[[The FADER]]|accessdate=March 24, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2017/03/khalid-featured-kendrick-lamar-the-heart-part-4/|title=Khalid Is Featured on Kendrick Lamar's New "The Heart Part 4"|publisher=XXL|accessdate=March 24, 2017}} The song contains [[Sampling (music)|samples]] from "Don't Tell a Lie about Me and I Won't Tell the Truth on You" by [[James Brown]] and "[[I Love You (Faith Evans song)|I Love You]]" by [[Faith Evans]]. ==Background and release== On March 23, 2017, Lamar shared an [[Instagram]] post of the [[Roman numerals|Roman numeral]] "IV" after deleting his prior Instagram posts.{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/72436-listen-to-kendrick-lamars-new-song-the-heart-part-4/|title=Listen to Kendrick Lamar’s New Song "The Heart Part 4"|publisher=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]|accessdate=23 March 2017}} That night, Lamar released the song through streaming services. This is the fourth installment in Lamar's "The Heart" song series. "The Heart Part 1" was released as a loose track in April 2010, while "Part 2" was featured on Lamar's ''[[Overly Dedicated]]'' mixtape, released later that same year. "Part 3," featuring [[Ab-Soul]] and [[Jay Rock]], preceded the release of ''[[Good Kid, M.A.A.D City|good kid, m.A.A.d city]]'' in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2017/03/23/new-music-kendrick-lamar-the-heart-part-4/|title=New Music: Kendrick Lamar – ‘The Heart Part 4’|date=March 24, 2017|work=[[Rap-Up]]|accessdate=March 24, 2017}} He finishes the song with the line, "Y'all got til April the 7th to get y'all shit together", hinting at the release date for his fourth album (the date turned out to be the day pre-orders opened and the release date was announced to be April 14).{{cite web|url=https://planetradio.co.uk/kiss-fresh/entertainment/music/kendrick-lamar-upcoming-album-release-date/|title=Kendrick Lamar's upcoming album HAS a release date|publisher=Planet Radio|accessdate=12 April 2017}} The song mentions [[Donald Trump]], while media outlets perceived it as a [[diss track]] to rappers [[Drake (musician)|Drake]] and [[Big Sean]].{{cite web|url=http://hiphopdx.com/news/id.42828/title.whos-kendrick-dissing-on-the-heart-part-4-big-sean-drake-donald-trump|title=Who's Kendrick Dissing On "The Heart Part 4"? Big Sean? Drake? ... Donald Trump?|work=[[HipHopDX]]|accessdate=March 26, 2017}} A portion of the instrumental, produced by [[The Alchemist (musician)|The Alchemist]], is used on the song "[[Fear (Kendrick Lamar song)|Fear]]" from Lamar's fourth album ''[[Damn (Kendrick Lamar album)|Damn]]'' (2017). ==Critical reception== On the day of its release, [[Pitchfork Media|''Pitchfork'']] named it Best New Track.{{cite web|title="The Heart Part 4" by Kendrick Lamar Review {{!}} Pitchfork|url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/tracks/18918-kendrick-lamar-the-heart-part-4/|website=pitchfork.com|accessdate=25 March 2017|language=en}} For ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''{{'}}s Eric Renner Brown, Lamar "infuses his boasts of success and wealth with a degree of lyrical nuance that elevates the track."{{Cite news |url=http://ew.com/music/2017/03/24/kendrick-lamar-heart-part-4-review/ |title=Kendrick Lamar's 'The Heart Part 4': EW Review |date=March 24, 2017 |work=Entertainment Weekly |access-date=March 29, 2017}} ==Charts== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" |- ! scope="col"| Chart (2017) ! scope="col"| Peak
position |- ! scope="row"| Australia ([[ARIA Charts|ARIA]]){{cite web|url=http://www.ariacharts.com.au/charts/singles-chart|title=ARIA Australian Top 50 Singles|publisher=[[Australian Recording Industry Association]]|date=April 3, 2017|accessdate=April 1, 2017}} | 35 |- ! scope="row"| Australia Urban ([[ARIA Charts|ARIA]]){{cite web|url=http://www.ariacharts.com.au/charts/urban-singles-chart|title=ARIA Urban Singles Chart|publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association|accessdate=April 1, 2017}} | 2 |- {{singlechart|Canada|25|artist=Kendrick Lamar|rowheader=true|accessdate=April 4, 2017}} |- ! scope="row"| France ([[Syndicat National de l'Édition Phonographique|SNEP]]){{cite web|url=http://www.snepmusique.com/tops-semaine/top-singles-telecharges/?ye=2017&we=13|title=Le Top de la semaine : Top Singles Téléchargés - SNEP (Week 13, 2017)|publisher=[[Syndicat National de l'Édition Phonographique]]|language=French|accessdate=April 1, 2017}} | 47 |- ! scope="row"| Ireland ([[Irish Recorded Music Association|IRMA]]){{cite web|url=http://irma.ie/index.cfm?page=irish-charts&chart=Singles|title=IRMA - Irish Charts|publisher=[[Irish Recorded Music Association]]|accessdate=April 1, 2017}} | 45 |- ! scope="row"| New Zealand Heatseekers ([[Recorded Music NZ|RMNZ]]){{cite web|url=http://nztop40.co.nz/chart/singles?chart=4345|title=NZ Heatseekers Singles Chart|publisher=[[Recorded Music NZ]]|date=April 3, 2017|accessdate=March 31, 2017}} | 2 |- {{singlechart|Scotland|64|date=2017-03-31|rowheader=true|accessdate=April 1, 2017}} |- {{singlechart|Switzerland|41|artist=Kendrick Lamar|song=The Heart Part 4|rowheader=true|accessdate=April 3, 2017}} |- {{singlechart|UK|61|date=2017-03-31|rowheader=true|accessdate=April 1, 2017}} |- {{singlechart|UKrandb|21|date=2017-03-31|rowheader=true|accessdate=April 1, 2017}} |- {{singlechart|Billboardhot100|22|artist=Kendrick Lamar|rowheader=true|accessdate=April 4, 2017}} |- {{singlechart|Billboardrandbhiphop|11|artist=Kendrick Lamar|rowheader=true|accessdate=April 4, 2017}} |} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{MetroLyrics song|kendrick-lamar|the-heart-part-4}} {{Kendrick Lamar songs}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Heart Part 4}} [[Category:2017 songs]] [[Category:Kendrick Lamar songs]] [[Category:Songs written by Kendrick Lamar]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by The Alchemist (musician)]] [[Category:Top Dawg Entertainment singles]] [[Category:Sequel songs]] [[Category:Songs about Donald Trump]] [[Category:Songs written by Khalid (singer)]] [[Category:Songs written by DJ Dahi]] [[Category:Songs written by The Alchemist (musician)]]

{{use mdy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox video game | title = The Incident | image = The Incident title.png | developer = Big Bucket Software | publisher = Big Bucket Software | released = '''iOS'''{{vgrelease|WW|August 10, 2010<ref name="iOS">{{cite web|url=http://ie.ign.com/games/the-incident/iphone-83238|title=The Incident (iPhone) |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=July 24, 2013}}</ref>}}'''OS X'''{{vgrelease|WW|January 6, 2011<ref name="OS">{{cite web|url=http://gigaom.com/2011/01/06/mac-app-store-launches-featuring-over-1000-apps/|title=Mac App Store Launches, Featuring Over 1,000 Apps|first=Darrell |last=Etherington|date=January 6, 2011 |publisher=GigaOM |accessdate=September 1, 2013}}</ref>}} | genre = [[Platform game|Platform]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] | platforms = [[iOS]], [[OS X]] }}
'''''The Incident''''' is a {{vgy|2010}} [[platform game]] developed and published by Australian studio Big Bucket Software. It was released on August 10, 2010 for [[iOS]] devices<ref name="iOS" /> and on January 6, 2011 for [[OS X]] (via the [[Mac App Store]]).<ref name="OS" />
==Gameplay== [[File:The Incident Screenshot.png|thumb|left|The player, climbing the growing pile of falling items, is nearing a checkpoint (represented by a rope of flags). On the left, a "curse" ballon floats up; on the right, a "boost" power-up.]] Two game modes are available for play in the game: a level-by-level campaign, titled "The Rise and Fall of Frank Solway", and an endless mode, titled "Endless Nightfall".
The basic gameplay involves random objects falling from the sky, as the player tries to avoid getting hit. Control is by means of tilting the device to move left or right and tapping on the [[touchscreen]] to jump.<ref name="IGN" /> As the game progresses, the pile of objects gets taller, and less stable. At random intervals, diamonds will fall that grant the player an [[1-up|extra life]] if collected; each level has a certain number of diamonds and the amount collected is recorded on the stage select screen. As well as falling diamonds, balloons arise from below the pile, carrying [[power-up]]s, such as coins (ten coins gives the player an extra life), a protective helmet that shields the player from damage for a limited time, an extra health unit (which cannot be replenished once lost), an item that scrolls the screen up or down, or a skull that damages the player (referred to as an "Ancient Curse").<ref name="KotakuReview"/> If the player finds himself stuck in the middle of the pile, he can attempt to shake the device to form a bubble and float back to the top.<ref name="1up" /> However, this is an unreliable feature.
"The Rise and Fall of Frank Solway" contains 7 levels, in which the player is required to climb 130 meters for the first five stages and 100 meters for the final two. To aid in this, several checkpoints are present throughout each level. Once a checkpoint is crossed, the player can restart from that position if he dies, with one replenished health unit.
Death can occur by the player being pushed off-screen by the pile or losing all health units. Items that kill the player are recorded in a museum and shown by name on the death screen (e.g. "Death by Taxi").
==Plot== Frank Solway, an [[average Joe]], is having an ordinary day. As he tries to hail a cab, he notices that the streets are eerily empty. He then notices something above him — which turns out to be a cab falling from the sky. He dodges it, only to find more objects of all descriptions raining down on him: sofas, houseplants, vending machines, pianos. Frank keeps dodging the falling debris and climbs the ever-growing pile. Gradually he rises above the city, past the nearby mountains, and into the sky, eventually leaving earth's orbit and reaching outer space, where he hopes to discover the source of the falling objects.
Frank eventually floats into a white void with what appears to be a portal in the middle. A slightly older Frank approaches from the other side. It is revealed that the older Frank also attempted to hail a cab, but instead it was sucked into the air, followed by other objects from his world; the portal drew objects from one world and deposited them in the other. Finally the two Franks touch the portal together, causing a bright light to fall on Frank's town, saving his world.
After the game is cleared once, the player can play through it again in "Beard Mode", as the older Frank.
==Updates== Since its initial release, the game has had two major updates. The 1.2 update allows players to use their [[iPhone]] or [[iPod Touch]] as a controller, while using an [[iPad]] as a screen.<ref name="KotakuWhatsNew">{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/#!5667074/whats-new-in-the-incident-12 |title=What's New In The Incident 1.2? |publisher=[[Kotaku]] |first=Michael|last= McWhertor |date=October 18, 2010 |accessdate=February 20, 2011}}</ref> The 1.3 update allows players to use a video cable with a suitable adapter attached to the iPad's [[Dock connector#Apple|dock connector]] to play the game on a television set or computer monitor, with the graphics reformatted to fit a [[High-definition television|HDTV]] screen.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bigbucketsoftware.com/2010/11/10/the-incident-1-3-making-it-work/|title=The Incident 1.3: Making It Work|publisher=Big Bucket Software|first=Matt|last= Comi|date=November 10, 2010|accessdate=April 1, 2011}}</ref>
==Reception== {{Video game reviews | title = ''The Incident'' |subtitle = (iOS version) |state = off | GR = 85.71%<ref name="GR" /> | MC = 82/100<ref name="MC" /> | 1UP = B+<ref name="1up" /> | IGN = 7.5/10<ref name="IGN" /> | rev1 = ''[[Gamezebo]]'' | rev1Score = 8/10<ref name="Gamezebo" /> | rev2 = ''[[Pocket Gamer]]'' | rev2Score = 7/10<ref name="pocket" /> | rev3 = TouchGen | rev3Score = {{Rating|4.5|5}}<ref name="TouchGen" /> }} ''The Incident'' was met with mainly positive reviews. The iOS version holds an aggregate score of 82 out of 100 on [[Metacritic]], based on sixteen reviews,<ref name="MC">{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/ios/the-incident|title=The Incident for iOS |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=July 24, 2013}}</ref> and 85.71% on [[GameRankings]], based on seven reviews.<ref name="GR">{{cite web |url=http://www.gamerankings.com/iphone/605016-the-incident/index.html|title=The Incident (iOS) |publisher=[[GameRankings]] |accessdate=July 24, 2013}}</ref>
The graphical style of the game, which was designed to emulate [[History of video game consoles (third generation)|8-bit games]], has been widely praised. [[Kotaku]] called it "attractively visually designed."<ref name="KotakuReview" /> TouchGen saw it as "a visual homage to games of yesteryear."<ref name="TouchGen">{{cite web |url= http://www.touchgen.net/the-incident-retro-goodness-coming-soon |publisher= TouchGen |first= Nigel |last=Wood |date= August 6, 2010 |title= The Incident - retro goodness coming soon|accessdate=July 24, 2013 }}</ref> Boing Boing's Brandon Broyer referred to it as "a simple idea executed with fantastic style."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.boingboing.net/2010/04/27/the-incident-a-game.html |publisher=Boing Boing |first= Brandon|last= Broyer |date= April 27, 2010 |title= The Incident: a game of 8-bit cataclysm|accessdate=July 24, 2013 }}</ref> [[Gamezebo]] wrote "the retro 8-bit presentation absolutely sparkles."<ref name="Gamezebo" />
Kotaku's editor Michael McWhertor was impressed with the overall game. He criticized the high difficulty near the end, but concluded that "it was the game's more clever references that appealed to me more than its graphics. There are amusing nods to films like ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey]]'' and ''[[Back to the Future]]'' and pop culture sources like ''[[Neon Genesis Evangelion]]'' and ''[[Mystery Science Theater 3000]]''. ''The Incident'' tickles your geek side expertly."<ref name="KotakuReview">{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/#!5625485/the-incident-review-its-a-happening--it-freaks-me-out |title=The Incident Review: It's A Happening & It Freaks Me Out |publisher=[[Kotaku]] |first=Michael|last= McWhertor |date=August 30, 2010 |accessdate=February 20, 2011}}</ref> McWhertor later referred to the game as "one of my favorite iPhone games of 2010", stating "I'm still surprisingly wowed by the option for wireless iPhone control."<ref name="KotakuWhatsNew"/>
[[Gamezebo]]'s Jim Squires scored the game 8 out of 10, writing "players looking for an accessible yet frantic arcade-style experience are going to really dig what ''The Incident'' has to offer [...] If you're looking for a new experience with old school arcade-style simplicity, ''The Incident'' is one item you'll want to catch." They also praised the music and sound design.<ref name="Gamezebo">{{cite web |url= http://www.gamezebo.com/iphone-games/incident/review|publisher= [[Gamezebo]] |first= Jim |last=Squires|date= August 10, 2010 |title= The Incident Review |accessdate=July 24, 2013 }}</ref> [[IGN]]'s Levi Buchanan rated the game 7.5 out of 10, writing "''The Incident'' is a prime example of how the best iPhone games are simple ideas, perfectly executed. The climb from the street to the stars is terrifically fun and addictive."<ref name="IGN">{{cite web |url= http://wireless.ign.com/articles/111/1111752p1.html|publisher= [[IGN]] |first= Levi |last=Buchanan|date= August 11, 2010 |title= The Incident Review |accessdate=July 24, 2013 }}</ref> TouchGen's Nigel Wood scored it 4.5 out of 5, writing "''The Incident'' is an incredibly cool game, delivering addictive arcade platforming wrapped in classic packaging. It's a budget beauty!"<ref name="TouchGen" />
[[Pocket Gamer]]'s Tracy Erickson scored the game 7 out of 10, arguing that it was enjoyable in the short term only; "''The Incident'' is entertaining for a few short minutes, yet its one-dimensional gameplay limits the long-lasting fun [...] An amusing game of evasion, ''The Incident'' holds little in the way of lasting appeal."<ref name="pocket">{{cite web |url= http://www.pocketgamer.co.uk/r/iPhone/The+Incident/review.asp?c=22757|publisher= [[Pocket Gamer]] |first= Tracy |last=Erickson|date= August 11, 2010 |title= The Incident Review |accessdate=July 24, 2013 }}</ref> Cole Jones of [[1UP.com|1UP]] rated it B+, feeling the gameplay became somewhat repetitive; "if you try to play for a couple hours straight, its repetitive nature starts to shine through. You'll enjoy this clever platformer, but only in short spurts."<ref name="1up">{{cite web |url= http://www.1up.com/reviews/the-incident-review |publisher= [[1UP.com]] |first= Cole |last=Jones |date= August 19, 2010 |title= The Incident Review |accessdate=November 19, 2014}}</ref>

{{infobox music genre|name=Tumba francesa |color=white |bgcolor=blue |stylistic_origins=18th century [[Afro-Haitian]] music |cultural_origins=Early 19th century in [[Oriente Province|Oriente]], [[Cuba]] |instruments=[[Catá]], premier, bulá, segón, tambora, chachá or maruga |subgenres= |derivatives= |image = Guantánamo CF9A1071.jpg |regional_scenes=[[Santiago de Cuba]], [[Guantánamo]] }} '''Tumba francesa''' is a secular Afro-Cuban genre of [[dance]], [[song]], and drumming that emerged in [[Oriente Province|Oriente]], [[Cuba]]. It was introduced by slaves from [[Haiti]]—then a French colony known as [[Saint-Domingue]]—whose owners resettled in Cuba's eastern regions following the [[Haitian Revolution|slave rebellion]] during the 1790s. The genre flourished in the late 19th century with the establishment of ''sociedades de tumba francesa'' (tumba francesa societies), of which only three survive.
==Characteristics== Tumba francesa combines musical traditions of [[West Africa]]n, [[Bantu peoples|Bantu]], [[Music of France|French]] and [[Music of Spain|Spanish]] origin. Cuban ethnomusicologists agree that the word "tumba" derives from the [[Bantu language|Bantu]] and [[Mandinka language|Mandinka]] words for drum.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ortiz |first=Fernando |authorlink=Fernando Ortiz Fernández |title=Los instrumentos de la música afrocubana, Vol. IV|date=1954|publisher=Cárdenas y cía|location=Havana, Cuba|page=114}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Alén|first1=Olavo|title=La música en las sociedades de tumba francesa|date=1986|publisher=Casa de las Américas|location=Havana, Cuba|page=45}}</ref> In Cuba, the word tumba is used to denote the drums, the ensembles and the performance itself in tumba francesa.<ref name="Ramos">{{cite book|last1=Ramos Venereo|first1=Zobeyda|editor1-last=Kuss|editor1-first=Malena|title=Music in Latin America and the Caribbean: An Encyclopedic History, Vol. 2|date=2007|publisher=University of Texas Press|location=Austin, TX|pages=265–280|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=uspTNzJ_NoYC|chapter=Haitian Traditions in Cuba}}</ref>
===Instrumentation=== Tumbas francesas are directed by a mistress of ceremonies called ''mayora de plaza''. Performances generally begin with improvised solo singing in a mixture of [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Haitian Creole|French patois]] termed ''kreyol cubano'' or ''patuá cubano'' by the lead vocalist (''composé'').<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Figueroa Arencibia|first1=Vicente Jesús|last2=Ourdy|first2=Pierre Jean|title=Contacto lingüístico español-kreyol en una comunidad cubano-haitiana de Santiago de Cuba|journal=Revista Internacional de Lingüística Iberoamericana|date=2004|volume=2|issue=2|pages=41–55|jstor=41678051}}</ref> After the introduction, the [[catá]] (a wooden cylindrical idiophone struck with two [[palitos|sticks]]) is played, and the ''composé'' alternates [[call and response (music)|call and response]] singing with a group of female vocalists (''tumberas'').<ref name="Ramos" /> After the catá establishes the beat, the three tumbas are played. The tumbas are single-headed hand drums; from largest to smallest they are called premier (or manma), bulá and segón. The premier is now commonly called quinto, as it fulfills the same lead, improvisatory role as the [[quinto (drum)|quinto]] does among the [[conga]] drums in [[Cuban rumba]].<ref name="Ramos" /> In the toque masón, a double-headed bass drum called tamborita (or simply tambora) establishes the rhythm together with the catá. In addition, a [[shaker (instrument)|shaker]] called chachá or maruga is commonly played by the ''tumberas'' and the ''mayora'' throughout the performance.<ref name="Ramos" /> The structure of tumba francesa is related to an eastern type of [[Cuban rumba]] called [[tahona]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Orovio|first1=Helio|title=Cuban Music from A to Z|date=2004|publisher=Tumi|location=Bath, UK|page=208|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=XGzKzOH9vawC}}</ref>
===Toques=== There are three main ''toques'', or types of tumba performance, each associated with a specific dance.
*Masón. This is the first toque. It features the whole music ensemble and is associated with a [[quadrille]]-style dance similar to the [[contradanza]]. *Yubá. This ''toque'' follows the masón and involves the catá and the three tumbas. It is accompanied by the main tumba dance, which is improvised. There are two subtypes of yubá: macota and cobrero.<ref name="Ramos" /> *Frenté (or fronté). Originally the final section of the yubá, this is now considered an individual ''toque''. It involves the catá, the premier and the bulá.<ref name="Ramos" /> It is played in front of the drums, hence the name.
An additional toque called ''cinta'' is only performed in [[Santiago de Cuba]]. It is called so because the performance takes place around a tree trunk with coloured bands (''cintas''), which are red, white and blue.
===Dance=== The dance in tumba francesa is similar to Haitian [[Affranchi (dance)|affranchi]], which involves a series of straight-backed, held-torso, French style figures followed by African improvisation on the final set,<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BN_49ho6AKkC&pg=PA60 |title=Caribbean and Atlantic Diaspora Dance: Igniting Citizenship |accessdate=18 March 2014}}</ref> but tumba francesa is danced to drums instead of string and woodwind instruments.<ref name="Daniel">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nhCRJ4u_CYIC |title=Dancing Wisdom: Embodied Knowledge in Haitian Vodou, Cuban Yoruba, and Bahian Candombié |author=Daniel, Yvonne |page=122 |accessdate=8 December 2014}}</ref> The clothes of the dancers are colorful and flamboyant.<ref name="UNESCO">{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/culture/ich/RL/00052 |title=La Tumba Francesa |publisher=UNESCO.org |date= |accessdate=16 January 2014}}</ref>
==History== Tumbas francesas can be traced back to the late 18th century when the [[Haitian Revolution]] triggered the migration of French colonists from Saint-Domingue, bringing their slaves to the [[Oriente Province]] of Cuba. By the late 19th century, following the abolition of slavery in 1886, tumba francesa societies became established in this region, especially in [[Santiago de Cuba]] and [[Guantánamo]]. Their establishment was in many ways similar to the old African ''cabildos''.<ref name="Ramos" /> Performers identify tumba francesa as ''French-Haitian'', acknowledging it as a product of Haiti which now resides in [[Cuba]].<ref name="Daniel" /> By the second half of the 20th century, tumbas francesas were still performed in eastern Cuba, especially the toque masón. Other toques however are only played in the context cultural associations. Three tumba francesa societies survive at the moment: La Caridad de Oriente (originally La Fayette) in Santiago de Cuba; Bejuco in [[Sagua de Tánamo]], [[Holguín Province|Holguín]]; and Santa Catalina de Riccis (originally La Pompadour) in Guantánamo.<ref name="Ramos" />
==Recordings== Unlike other Afro-Cuban genres, tumba francesa remains poorly documented in terms of recordings. The 1976 LP ''Antología de la música afrocubana VII'', produced by Danilo Orozco and released by [[Areito (record label)|Areito]], presents a variety of yubá and masón toques.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Alén|first1=Olavo|title=Liner notes of Antología de la música afrocubana VII|date=1976|publisher=Areito|location=Havana, Cuba}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Cuban rumba]] *[[Music of Cuba]] *[[Music of Haiti]]

{{refimprove|date=September 2016}}
'''''Twisted Showcase''''' is a [[Great Britain|British]] independent series described as a mixture of self-contained [[horror genre|horror]], [[science fiction|sci-fi]], psychological thriller, and [[comedy]].
Twisted Showcase was created by Robin Bell and Rhys Jones who wanted to make something different with a strong focus on story. They both [[television writer|write]] for the [[television series|series]] and are [[producer (television)|producer]]s of the show. Each [[television episode|episode]] is a standalone story which aims to shock, amaze and entertain.
Twisted Showcase was recognized in 2012 when it was named in The Guardian top 25 must watch web shows, the only British series in the top 25.
A third series was produced for 2014 with episodes featuring ''Red Dwarf'' actor [[Norman Lovett]] and ''[[Torchwood]]'' and ''[[Doctor Who]]'' star [[Gareth David-Lloyd]].
A fourth series was slated for release in 2016 with an episode called "Muscle Memory" written by [[Debbie Moon]] and an episode featuring Gareth David-Lloyd's directorial debut.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.twistedshowcase.com/news/2015/10/27/debbie-moon-writing-an-episode-for-series-4.html|title=Debbie Moon writing an episode for Series 4|date=27 October 2015|accessdate=17 August 2016}}</ref> The fourth season did not end up premiering until October 2017 with the episode, "Be My Head."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.twistedshowcase.com/home/2017/10/3/be-my-head.html|title=Be My Head|date=3 October 2017|accessdate=28 February 2018}}</ref>

revision.text:
[[File:Cyprianus.jpg|thumb|right|This printed ''[[Cyprianus]]'' (Copenhagen, 1916) promises the list of Tycho Brahe Days.]] In the [[Scandinavian folklore|folklore of Scandinavia]], '''Tycho Brahe days''' ([[Danish language|Danish]]: ''Tycho Brahes-dage''; [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]]: ''Tycho Brahedager''; [[Swedish language|Swedish]]: ''Tycho Brahe-dagar'') are [[calendar date|days]] judged to be especially [[luck|unlucky]], especially for [[magic (paranormal)|magical]] work, and important business transactions[ and personal events]. [[Tycho Brahe]] (1546–1601) was a [[Danes|Danish]] [[astronomy|astronomer]], [[astrology|astrologer]],<ref name="Tycho Brahe and Astrology">{{cite web | url=http://www.tychobrahe.com/uk/astrologi.html | title=Tycho Brahe och Astrology | publisher=The Tycho Brahe Museum | accessdate=October 14, 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120503102927/http://www.tychobrahe.com/uk/astrologi.html | archivedate=May 3, 2012 | df= }}</ref> and [[alchemy|alchemist]] and as such achieved some acclaim in popular folklore as a sage and magician.
==Origins== The idea that certain calendar dates are lucky or unlucky is of ancient origin, going back as far as the [[Mesopotamian civilization]]s. Tables that identify lucky and unlucky days are sometimes known by the German label of ''Tagwählerei''. The [[Coligny calendar]] also identifies certain calendar dates as lucky or unlucky, and the Roman ''[[fasti]]'' marks many days and parts of others as ''dies nefasti'', unsuited for the conduct of public business.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/secondary/SMIGRA*/Dies.html | title=A Dictionary of Greek and Roman Antiquities | publisher=John Murray | year=1875 | accessdate=October 15, 2012 | author=Smith, William | pages="Dies"}}</ref> Contemporary North America preserves a tradition that [[Friday the 13th]] is an unlucky day. It has been called a "pervasive form of divination" that "is found in all societies which regulate their days and nights in calendric systems."<ref name="Koch">{{cite web | url=https://www.academia.edu/493008/Concepts_and_Perception_of_Time_in_Mesopotamian_Divination | title=Concepts and Perception of Time in Mesopotamian Divination | publisher=academia.edu | year=2010 | accessdate=October 14, 2012 | author=Koch, Ulla Suzanne | pages=7}}</ref>
The received idea concerning the origin of Tycho Brahe days was that "Tycho Brahe, the celebrated Danish astronomer of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, was very superstitious, considering certain days in the year pregnant with misfortune, wherefore in Denmark, up to this very day, the laboring class call such days on which they happen to meet with some unfortunate accident, Tycho Brahe's days."<ref>{{cite book | title=The Ancient Scandinavians, their maritime expeditions, their discoveries, and their religion | publisher=Hunter Rose & Co | author=Sinding, Paul O. | year=1865 | location=[http://www27.us.archive.org/stream/cihm_47513#page/n21/mode/2up/search/Tycho+Brahe Internet Archive digitized edition] | pages=19}}</ref> In his travelogue ''A Poet's Bazaar'', [[Hans Christian Andersen]] alludes to the fact that Tycho Brahe died in exile in Prague, observing that "Denmark owns not even his dust; but the Danes mention his name in their bad times, as if a denunciation proceeded out of it: 'These are Tycho Brahe's days!' say they."<ref name="Andersen">{{cite web | url=http://www.ebooksread.com/authors-eng/h-c-hans-christian-andersen/a-poets-bazaar--a-picturesque-tour-in-germany-italy-greece-and-the-orient-ala/page-30-a-poets-bazaar--a-picturesque-tour-in-germany-italy-greece-and-the-orient-ala.shtml | title=The Poet's Bazaar: a picturesque tour in Germany, Italy, Greece, and the Orient | publisher=Houghton Mifflin | year=1831 | accessdate=October 14, 2012 | author=[[Hans Christian Andersen|Andersen, Hans C.]]}}</ref>
However, no mention of the Tycho Brahe days is actually found in the work of Tycho Brahe.<ref name="Thoren">{{cite book | title=The Lord of Uraniborg: A Biography of Tycho Brahe | publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] | author=Thoren, Victor | year=1991 | pages=215 | isbn=0521351588}}</ref> They nevertheless are often referenced in [[almanac]]s and recur in Scandinavian folklore. In the [[Cyprianus]] tradition, Tycho Brahe days are considered unlucky for magical work; several of the spells in the ''Black Books of Elverum'' note that they should not be carried out on a Tycho Brahe day.<ref>Rustad, Mary: ''The Black Books of Elverum'' (Galde Press, 1999; {{ISBN|1-880090-75-9}}), e.g. p. 49, 116-117</ref><ref>Stokker, Kathleen: ''Remedies and rituals: folk medicine in Norway and the New Land'' (Minnesota Historical Society, 2007; {{ISBN|0-87351-576-5}}), p. 79</ref>
==Days== :''Based on the [[Julian calendar]]''
*January 1, 2, 4, 6, 11, 12, 29 *February 11, 17, 18 *March 1, 4, 14, 15 *April 9, 16, 17, 18, 19, 22, 29 *May 10, 17, 18 *June 6 *July 17, 21 *August 20, 21 *September 16, 18 *October 6 *November 6, 16 *December 6, 11, 18<ref name="Marryat">{{cite book | title=A residence in Jutland, the Danish Isles, and Copenhagen | publisher=J. Murray | author=Marryat, Horace | year=1860 | location=[https://books.google.com/books?id=dZfxsrZMt50C&pg=PA309&lpg=PA309&dq=%22Tycho+Brahe+days%22&source=bl&ots=rLJhtMM3kS&sig=onuYE0Pv0Uh0TgjtFPrnPWsA6DA&hl=en&sa=X&ei=6E16UOKQGdKFyQGv9YC4Ag&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=%22Tycho%20Brahe%20days%22&f=false Google scan] | pages=309}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Tykobrahedag - Institutet för språk och folkminnen|url = http://www.sprakochfolkminnen.se/folkminnen/handelser-i-almanackan/kalender/i-almanackan/handelser-i-almanackan/2014-02-14-tykobrahedag.html|website = www.sprakochfolkminnen.se|access-date = 2016-02-22|language = sv|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160214092117/http://www.sprakochfolkminnen.se/folkminnen/handelser-i-almanackan/kalender/i-almanackan/handelser-i-almanackan/2014-02-14-tykobrahedag.html|archivedate = 2016-02-14|df = }}</ref> These days were supposed to be unlucky to perform tasks such as getting married, starting a journey, or to fall ill on.<ref>Marryat</ref> Some versions claim that Tycho Brahe also identified several days as particularly lucky: *January 26 *February 9 and 10 *June 15<ref>{{Cite web|title = Tycho Brahe-days|url = http://www.learning4sharing.nu/tykobrahedag-344403.html|website = www.learning4sharing.nu|access-date = 2016-02-22|language = sv}}</ref> Some lists omit certain days, or add others; there is no standard list. One should also note that Denmark was on the [[Julian calendar]] until 1700, when it switched to the [[Gregorian calendar]].<ref name="The Perpetual Calendar">{{cite web | url=http://norbyhus.dk/calendar.php | title=The Perpetual Calendar: A helpful Tool to Postal Historians | publisher=norbyhus.dk | accessdate=October 14, 2012 | author=Nørby, Toke}}</ref>
===Egyptian days=== Medieval calendars often contained lists of ''dies Ægyptiaci'', "Egyptian days", that also were held to be unlucky. The Egyptian days were: *January 1, 25 *February 4, 26 *March 1, 28 *April 10, 20 *May 3, 25 *June 10, 16 *July 13, 22 *August 1,30 *September 3, 21 *October 3, 22 *November 5, 28 *December 7, 22 These too were days considered unlucky to begin any enterprise. Physicians were especially discouraged from performing [[bloodletting]] on the Egyptian days.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.worldwidewords.org/weirdwords/ww-egy1.htm |title=World Wide Words: Egyptian Days |last=Quinion |first=Michael |date=Mar 3, 2007 |access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref><ref>Schmitz, Wilh. “Ein Wolfenbütteler Verzeichnitz Der 'Dies Aegyptiaci'.” ''Rheinisches Museum Für Philologie'', vol. 22, 1867, pp. 303–303. JSTOR, JSTOR, www.jstor.org/stable/23078686.</ref>
==See also== *[[Friday the 13th]]

'''Video gaming in South Africa''' is the largest market in Africa.<ref>{{cite news|title= Video gaming tops R1.7 billion |work= Biz|date=|url= http://www.bizcommunity.com/Article/196/185/76182.html|accessdate=2012-01-21}}</ref> The market is overtaking the market in movies and music in the country.<ref>{{cite news|title= Local Gaming Bigger than Movies and Music?|work=Gaming|date=|url= http://gaming.do.co.za/articles/localnews/local_gaming_bigger_than_movies_and_music.htm|accessdate=2012-01-21}}</ref>
Whilst the American market for video games has declined, it is increasing in South Africa.<ref>{{cite news|title= The South African Game Development Scene: Past, Present, and Future|work=Animation SA|date=|url= http://animationsa.org/articles/south-african-game-development-scene-past-present-and-future|accessdate=2012-01-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= 31 May 2012: SA Video Gaming Industry Worth R1.7b|work= Cape Business News|date=|url= http://www.cbn.co.za/dailynews/6226.html|accessdate=2012-01-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= South Africa Game Sales Continue to Rise|work= Gaming|date=|url=http://gaming.do.co.za/articles/localnews/south_africa_game_sales_continue_to_rise.htm|accessdate=2012-01-21}}</ref>
[[South Africa]] boasts Expos, relatively big LAN's and a growing community of gamer's. [[South Africa]]'s biggest [[LAN]] event called the NAG LAN<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.naglan.co.za/ |title=Nag Lan |publisher=Nag Lan |date= |accessdate=2016-09-26}}</ref> of the former magazine company moved to Cape Town in 2016 which had an impressive turnout. Another LAN event was held in Cape Town which was only slightly smaller than the NAG LAN with 400 people. Although the gaming community in Cape Town is big, the uncontested giant in South African gaming is Johannesburg, with [[Gauteng]] in its entirety housing more gamer's than the rest of the country.
Plans are also laid out by SuperSport to start an eSport channel with GINX eSports TV as the demand for streaming eSports keeps on growing.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://mybroadband.co.za/news/broadband/202508-supersport-esports-channel-gets-launch-date.html|title=SuperSport eSports channel gets launch date|access-date=2017-03-30|language=en-US}}</ref>
Thanks to big tech companies like [http://www.mweb.co.za/games/home.aspx MWEB] and [http://telkomgaming.co.za/ Telkom] whom host local server game servers which improve gaming allot in South Africa. This helps local competitive gaming to improve and bringing the local gaming community together.
One problem that South Africa is undertaking is the struggle to get protection from the government for Game Developers. There is a "ball-passing" going on at the different departments. The Dep. of Trade, Arts and Culture and Sports are still discussing which one will take the authority of handling the rights of game developers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.fin24.com/Tech/News/sa-gaming-industry-suffering-under-regulation-20160516|title=SA gaming industry 'suffering' under regulation|work=Fin24|access-date=2017-03-30}}</ref>
==Compared to the rest of Africa== South Africa's video gaming compared to the rest of Africa is unchallenged due to the large number of wealthy South Africans living in cities like [[Durban]], [[Cape Town]], [[Pretoria]], [[Bloemfontein]] and [[Johannesburg]]. With internet infrastructure being more than sufficient to support the sport. With Fibre being almost fully integrated in cities and wealthy suburban areas the growth in online gaming can only be motivated. Video game developing in the country is not doing well, but events and [[eSports]] organizations like [[Mind Sports South Africa]], the Digital Gaming League,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.digitalgamingleague.co.za/ |title=Home |publisher=Digital Gaming League |date= |accessdate=2016-09-26}}</ref> Orena<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.orena.co.za/news/ |title=Orena |publisher=Orena |date= |accessdate=2016-09-26}}</ref> and LANX<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lanx.co.za|title=LAN X|website=LANX|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-30}}</ref> have jumped up in 2015 with the big demand for eSports tournaments and other gaming events in large cities. However, it is only [[Mind Sports South Africa]] that continually holds events in all the provinces and runs school events. With gaming in schools also in the rise,<ref>{{cite web|author=Brendyn Lotz |url=http://www.htxt.co.za/2015/09/17/mssa-to-grow-esports-at-schools/ |title=Mind Sports South Africa to grow eSports at schools - htxt.africa |website=Htxt.co.za |date=2015-09-17 |accessdate=2016-09-26}}</ref> [[Mind Sports South Africa]] reports that there are now over 30 schools that participate in the official league, with school teams competing on an equal footing with many of the best private clubs in the country.
Nigeria, Kenya and Uganda are the other top game developers in Africa.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.howwemadeitinafrica.com/africas-gaming-industry-expert-shares-her-thoughts/|title=Africa's gaming industry: Expert shares her thoughts|date=2015-09-01|work=How We Made It In Africa|access-date=2017-03-30|language=en-US}}</ref> The gaming industry is bringing millions of dollars in for their countries per year. This is in all categories of gaming: mobile, PC, Xbox, and PS. Because it was not the culture of the African people, the people are slowly growing into the gaming entertainment.
[[South Africa]] also being dominant in sport in the continent and all over the world, and the country too has made its mark on the [[eSport]] scene as the national [[South African]] team has participated in every [[International e-Sports Federation]] world Championship since 2009 over a varied number of games and platforms. But [[Mind Sports South Africa]] has admitted that the gaming scene needs to mature.
Further proof that South Africa is highly respected is that Thomas Brown was selected to referee at the 2016 World Cyber Arena (WCA) in Beijing, and that on 31 July 2016 Jason Batzofin was elected onto [[International e-Sports Federation]] Athletes' Commission.

{{refimprove|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox company | name = White Wolf Publishing | logo = [[File:White Wolf Publishing logo.png|Logo of White Wolf Publishing.]] | type = Subsidiary | foundation = 1991 | location = Stockholm, Sweden | key_people = | industry = Role-playing games | products = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = Independent (1991-2006)
[[CCP Games]] (2006-2015)
[[Paradox Interactive]] (2015-present) | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.white-wolf.com/ white-wolf.com] | footnotes = }} '''White Wolf Publishing''' is a [[roleplaying game]] and book publisher. The company was founded in 1991 as a merger between [[Lion Rampant (game publisher)|Lion Rampant]][http://www.rpg.net/columns/briefhistory/briefhistory10.phtml A Brief History of Game #10: Lion Rampant: 1987-1990], RPGnet (Retrieved 14 June 2007) and ''White Wolf Magazine'' (est. 1986 in Rocky Face, GA; it later became "White Wolf Inphobia"), and was initially led by [[Mark Rein·Hagen]] of the former and [[Steve Wieck]] and [[Stewart Wieck]] of the latter. Since White Wolf Publishing, Inc. merged with [[CCP Games]] in 2006,{{cite web|url=http://www.ccpgames.com/en/company/merger.aspx|title=Home - CCP Games|work=ccpgames.com}} White Wolf Publishing has been an imprint of CCP hf, but has ceased in-house production of any material, instead licensing their properties to other publishers. It was announced in October 2015 that White Wolf had been acquired from CCP by [[Paradox Interactive]].{{cite web|title=Paradox Interactive Acquires White Wolf Publishing from CCP Games|url=https://www.paradoxplaza.com/news/Paradox-White-Wolf-Publishing/|accessdate=20 November 2015}} The name "White Wolf" originates from [[Michael Moorcock]]'s works. ==Overview== White Wolf published a line of several different but overlapping games set in the "[[World of Darkness]]", a "modern [[gothic fiction|gothic]]" world that, while seemingly similar to the real world, is home to supernatural terrors, ancient conspiracies, and several approaching [[apocalypse]]s. The company also published the high fantasy ''[[Exalted]]'' RPG, the modern mythic [[Scion (role-playing game)|''Scion'']], and [[d20 system]] material under their [[Sword and Sorcery Studios|Sword & Sorcery]] imprint, including such titles as the ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'' gothic horror campaign setting ''[[Ravenloft]]'', and [[Monte Cook]]'s ''[[Arcana Unearthed]]'' series. In order to complement the ''World of Darkness'' game line, a [[live action role-playing game|LARP]] system dubbed ''[[Mind's Eye Theatre]]'' has been published. White Wolf also released several series of novels based on the [[Old World of Darkness]], all of which are currently out of print (although many are coming back into availability via print-on-demand). White Wolf also ventured in the [[collectible card game]] market with [[Arcadia (card game)|''Arcadia'']], [[Rage (collectible card game)|''Rage'']], and ''[[Vampire: The Eternal Struggle]]'' (formerly ''Jyhad''). ''V:TES'', perhaps the most successful card game, was originally published by [[Wizards of the Coast]] in 1994, but was abandoned just two years later after a revamped base set, name change and three expansions were published. White Wolf acquired the rights to the game in 2000, even though no new material had been produced for the game in over four years. Since then, several ''V:TES'' expansions have been released, and the game was the only official source of material for the [[Old World of Darkness]], until 2011 when the 20th Anniversary Edition of ''[[Vampire: The Masquerade]]'' was published and the [[World of Darkness#The Onyx Path|Onyx Path]] was announced.{{cite web|url=http://www.white-wolf.com/community/news/white-wolf-release-schedule-2011-2012| title=White Wolf Release Schedule 2011-2012| publisher=White Wolf Publishing|accessdate=2011-08-09}} [[Video game]]s such as ''[[Vampire: The Masquerade - Redemption]]'' and ''[[Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines]]'' are based on White Wolf's role-playing game ''[[Vampire: The Masquerade]]''. There are also several [[Hunter: The Reckoning#Video games|''Hunter: The Reckoning'' video games]]. ===Merger and MMO=== On Saturday, 11 November 2006, White Wolf and [[CCP Games]], the Icelandic MMO development company responsible for [[EVE Online]], announced a merger between the two companies during the keynote address at the EVE Online Fanfest 2006. It was also revealed that a World of Darkness [[MMORPG]] was already in the planning stages. This game was cancelled in April 2014 after nine years of development.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/jun/05/world-of-darkness-the-inside-story-mmo-ccp-white-wolf|title=World of Darkness - the inside story on the death of a game|author=Ian G Williams|work=the Guardian}} ===The Onyx Path=== {{Main|Onyx Path Publishing}} At [[GenCon]] 2012 it was announced that CCP Games/White Wolf would not continue to produce table-top RPGs {{citation needed|date=October 2013}}. Onyx Path Publishing, a new company by White Wolf Creative Director Richard Thomas, purchased the Trinity games and Scion from CCP and became licensee for the production of World of Darkness titles (classic and new), as well as [[Exalted]]. Onyx Path does not, however, hold a license to the [[Mind's Eye Theatre]] titles. ===Purchase By Paradox Interactive=== On Thursday, 29 October 2015, [[Paradox Interactive]] and CCP announced that Paradox had purchased White Wolf and all of its intellectual properties. [[Tobias Sjögren]] will serve as the CEO of the revived company, which will remain a subsidiary of Paradox. Martin Ericsson, formerly a developer on the World of Darkness MMO, will be serving in the "Lead Storyteller" role for the company. ==RPG Products== ===The "Old" or "Classic" World of Darkness game lines=== The games of this series use White Wolf's [[Storyteller System]]. Several games inspired spinoffs in the form of "historical" [[period piece|period]] settings such as the [[Dark Ages (historiography)|Dark Ages]]. {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *''[[Vampire: The Masquerade]]'' (including the spinoffs ''[[Vampire: The Dark Ages]]''/''[[Dark Ages: Vampire]]'' and ''[[Victorian Age: Vampire]]'') *''[[Werewolf: The Apocalypse]]'' (including the spinoffs ''[[Werewolf: The Wild West]]'' and ''[[Werewolf: The Dark Ages]]''/''[[Dark Ages: Werewolf]]'') *''[[Mage: The Ascension]]'' (including the spinoffs ''[[Mage: The Sorcerers Crusade]]'' and ''[[Dark Ages: Mage]]'') *''[[Wraith: The Oblivion]]'' (including the spinoff ''[[Wraith: The Great War]]'') *''[[Changeling: The Dreaming]]'' (including the spinoff ''[[Dark Ages: Fae]]'') *''[[Kindred of the East]]'' (including the spinonff ''[[Blood and Silk]]'') *''[[Hunter: The Reckoning]]'' (including the semi-spinoff ''[[Dark Ages: Inquisitor]]'') *''[[Mummy: The Resurrection]]'' *''[[Demon: The Fallen]]'' (including the spinoff ''[[Dark Ages: Devil's Due]]'') *''[[Orpheus (role-playing game)|Orpheus]]'' }} In addition to those game lines a series of books was produced under the title ''World of Darkness''. These provided stand-alone materials for multiple game lines with the focus on a specific region or theme, e.g. ''WoD: Blood dimmed Tides'' (about the oceans), ''WoD: Combat'' (an alternative 'crossover' combat system to resolve contradictory mechanics and add some sophistication), ''WoD: Tokyo'' and ''WoD: Mafia''. For the Third Edition of ''[[Ars Magica]]'', White Wolf connected that game's pseudo-historical setting to the 'future' ''World of Darkness'' setting. This was a simple adjustment (since the core premise of both settings is 'Earth as we know it' + 'supernatural fiction is reality') and particularly suited to the 'Tremere connection' between a clan of vampires from the original ''Vampire'' and a House of magi in the ''[[Order of Hermes (disambiguation)|Order of Hermes]]'' (the central organization of ''Ars Magica'' as well as one of the 'Traditions' in ''[[Mage: The Ascension|M:TA]])''. ===The Chronicles of Darkness game lines=== The games of this series use White Wolf's newer [[Storytelling System]]. For over a decade it was also known as "World of Darkness," causing it to be referred to as the "new World of Darkness" or nWoD to distinguish it from the prior line of games. In December 2015, it was renamed "Chronicles of Darkness"{{cite web|url=http://theonyxpath.com/announcing-chronicles-of-darkness/|title=Announcing Chronicles of Darkness!|author=|date=|website=theonyxpath.com|accessdate=2 April 2018}} by its new publisher Onyx Path in order to more clearly distinguish the two given Paradox Entertainment's intention to reboot the original setting. {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *''[[Vampire: The Requiem]]'' *''[[Werewolf: The Forsaken]]'' *''[[Mage: The Awakening]]'' *''[[Promethean: The Created]]'' *''[[Changeling: The Lost]]'' *''[[Hunter: The Vigil]]'' *''[[Geist: The Sin-Eaters]]'' *''[[Mummy: The Curse]]'' *''[[Demon: The Descent]]'' *''[[Beast: The Primordial]]'' }} ===Age of Sorrows=== *[[Exalted (role-playing game)|''Exalted'']] ===Trinity Universe=== *''[[Trinity (role-playing game)|Trinity]]'' ([[science fiction]] and [[psionics (role-playing games)|psychics]]) *''[[Aberrant]]'' (near-future [[superhero]]es) *''[[Adventure!]]'' (1920s pulp heroes) ===Other=== * ''[[Pendragon (role-playing game)|Pendragon]]'' * ''[[Scion (role-playing game)|Scion]]'' * ''[[Street Fighter: The Storytelling Game]]'' * ''[[Engel (role-playing game)|Engel]]'' ==Mind's Eye Theatre (LARP)== The majority of the Old World of Darkness games were adapted into the original [[Mind's Eye Theatre]] format for live-action roleplaying. Product lines in this era include: {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *''[[Laws of the Night]]'' (formerly ''Masquerade''; based on ''[[Vampire: The Masquerade]]'') *''[[Laws of the Wild]]'' (formerly ''Apocalypse''; based on ''[[Werewolf: The Apocalypse]]'') *''[[Oblivion (role-playing game)|Oblivion]]'' (based on ''[[Wraith: The Oblivion]]'') *''[[Laws of the Hunt]]'' (focusing on mortals as characters) *''[[The Long Night (role-playing game)|The Long Night]]'' (based on ''[[Vampire: The Dark Ages]]'') *''[[The Shining Host]]'' (based on ''[[Changeling: The Dreaming]]'') *''[[Laws of the Wyld West]]'' (based on ''[[Werewolf: The Wild West]]'') *''[[Laws of Ascension]]'' (based on ''[[Mage: The Ascension]]'') *''[[Laws of the Reckoning]]'' (based on ''[[Hunter: The Reckoning]]'') *''[[Laws of Resurrection]]'' (based on ''[[Mummy: The Resurrection]]'') *''[[Laws of the East]]'' (based on ''[[Kindred of the East]]'') *''[[Faith and Fire]]'' (based on ''[[Dark Ages: Vampire]]'') *''[[Vampire by Gaslight]]'' (based on ''[[Victorian Age: Vampire]]'') }} Subsequently, the Mind's Eye Theatre was revamped for the New World of Darkness. A core ''Mind's Eye Theatre'' rulebook was published as the LARP analogue to the ''World of Darkness'' core rulebook, with several Mind's Eye Theatre adaptations following in suit: ''The Requiem'', ''The Forsaken'', and ''The Awakening'' each adapted their respective namesakes to the new system of MET rules. The license to produce Mind's Eye Theatre content was acquired by By Night Studios in 2013. ===By Night Studios=== At Midwinter Gaming Convention in 2013 it was announced that as a result of CCP Games discontinuation of publishing, By Night Studios had acquired the license to all [[Mind's Eye Theatre]] titles. In May 2013, By Night Studios launched a successful Kickstarter campaign{{cite web|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/bynightstudios/minds-eye-theatre-vampire-the-masquerade|title=Mind's Eye Theatre: Vampire The Masquerade Kickstarter|author=Night Studios|work=Kickstarter}} to rebuild the Mind's Eye Theatre: Vampire The Masquerade product specifically for the Live-Action Role Play audience. By Night Studios is currently in development of Mind's Eye Theatre: Werewolf The Apocalypse in the same rebuilding fashion as Vampire The Masquerade. ==Fiction== In the 1990s, White Wolf also published fiction. This included novels and anthologies based on White Wolf's games, as well as general fantasy and horror fiction. [[Neil Barron]], ''Fantasy and Horror: A Critical and Historical Guide to Literature, Illustration, Film, TV, Radio, and the Internet'', Scarecrow Press, 1999 {{ISBN|0810835967}} (p.431) White Wolf printed several [[Elric of Melniboné]] collections by [[Michael Moorcock]].Diana Tixier Herald, ''Fluent in Fantasy: A Guide to Reading Interests''. Libraries Unlimited, 1999 {{ISBN|1563086557}} (p.20). The company also put out general fiction collections by [[Harlan Ellison]], as well as several paperback editions of the "Borderlands" anthologies edited by [[Thomas F. Monteleone]]."Monteleone, Thomas F(rancis)", by [[Don D'Ammassa]] in [[David Pringle]], ''St. James Guide to Horror, Ghost & Gothic Writers''. London : St. James Press, 1998, {{ISBN|978-1-55862-206-7}} (pp. 414-5). ===Imprints and labels=== White Wolf has different imprints under which various books are published, most notably: * Arthaus - products for which White Wolf serves as publisher, not developer * [[Black Dog Game Studio|Black Dog Game Factory]] - adult themed products (defunct) * Sword & Sorcery - products compatible with the d20 system by [[Wizards of the Coast]] Black Dog Game Factory was also a fictional company in the World of Darkness, as detailed in the ''Subsidiaries: A Guide to Pentex'' game supplement. ==See also== *[[Sword and Sorcery Studios]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.whitewolf-publishing.com/ White Wolf] - Official web site. [[Category:American speculative fiction publishers]] [[Category:White Wolf Publishing| ]] [[Category:Role-playing game publishing companies]] [[Category:Game manufacturers]] [[Category:Card game publishing companies]] [[Category:Publishing companies established in 1991]] [[Category:Horror book publishing companies]] [[Category:1991 establishments in Georgia (U.S. state)]]

{{other uses}} [[File:Xintiandi5.jpg|thumb|upright|View of Xintiandi.]] [[File:Location of the First Congress of the Chinese Communist Party Xintiandi Shanghai July 1921.jpg|thumb|upright|Location of the first Congress of the [[Chinese Communist Party]] in July 1921, Xintiandi.]]
'''Xintiandi''' ({{zh|c=新天地|p=Xīntiāndì}}, <small>[[Shanghainese]]</small>: ''Shintidi'' <small>lit.</small> "New Heaven and Earth",<ref name="Warr A">Warr, Anne: ''Shanghai Architecture'', The Watermark Press, 2007, {{ISBN|978-0-949284-76-1}}</ref> <small>fig.</small> "New World") is an affluent [[pedestrian zone|car-free]] shopping, eating and entertainment district of [[Shanghai]].<ref>{{cite book| first=Christopher | last=Pitts| title=Pocket Shanghai | publisher=[[Lonely Planet]] | isbn=978-1-74179-963-7 | date=April 2013 | edition=3rd | pages=60–61 | chapter=Top Sights: Xintiandi }}</ref>
==Overview== The district is composed of an area of reconstituted traditional mid-19th century [[shikumen]] ("stone gate") houses on narrow alleys, some adjoining houses which now serve as book stores, cafes and restaurants, and shopping malls. Most of the cafes and restaurants feature both indoor and outdoor seating. Xintiandi has an active nightlife on weekdays as well as weekends, though romantic settings are more common than loud music and dance places. It is considered one of the first [[Lifestyle center (retail)|lifestyle center]]s in China. It is also the most expensive place to live in China, with some apartments costing more than Tokyo, New York and London. It is home to the Chinese elite and top executive expats.
Xintiandi is the location of the site of the first congress of the [[Communist Party of China]], now preserved at the [[Museum of the First National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party]]. Also nearby are the [[Shikumen Open House Museum]] and the site of the [[Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea]] when Korea was a Japanese colony.
[[File:Xintiandi gem.jpg|thumb|Renovated shikumen lane in Xintiandi.]]
==Redevelopment== The area was developed by [[Shui On Land]] during the re-development of the surrounding area. Some houses in Xintiandi were then demolished and rebuilt (not merely "renovated", which was the term used officially by the Chinese government and the real estate agencies<ref name="Xintiandi">[http://www.consulfrance-shanghai.org/Xintiandi.html Xintiandi]</ref>), in order to implant an art gallery, cafes, and restaurants. Many tour groups both domestic and from abroad also visit Xintiandi as one of the main attractions in Shanghai.
The Xintiandi redevelopment was designed by [[Benjamin T. Wood]] and [[Nikken Sekkei]] International. The urban renewal is considered one of the first examples of the [[placemaking]] approach in China.<ref name="Xintiandi Architect">[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/13/arts/design/13iovi.html Our Man in Shanghai: Ben Wood Takes On History]</ref>)
This construction displaced 3,500 Shanghainese families.<ref name="Xintiandi"/>
==Transportation== The closest [[Shanghai Metro]] stations in the vicinity are [[South Huangpi Road Station]] (on [[Line 1, Shanghai Metro|Line 1]]), and [[Xintiandi Station]] (on [[Line 10, Shanghai Metro|Line 10]]).
==See also== *[[Tianzifang]] *[[50 Moganshan Road]]

[[File:Émile Perrin - Ivor Guest 1981 p62f.jpg|thumb|<center>Émile Perrin</center>]] '''Émile-César-Victor Perrin''' was a French painter, mainly known as a theatre director and impresario, born in [[Rouen]] on 9 January 1814, died 8 October 1885.<ref name="Dean">Dean W. ''Bizet.'' London, JM Dent & Sons, 1978.</ref> His son-in-law was [[Camille du Locle]].<ref>Budden J. ''Verdi''. London, J M Dent & Sons, 1985.</ref>
==Biography== Perrin studied under [[Antoine-Jean Gros|Gros]] and [[Hippolyte Delaroche|Delaroche]], and pursued a career as a [[History painting|history painter]], exhibiting at the [[Salon (Paris)|Salon]]. In between his appointments at the Opéra-Comique he briefly returned to painting.<ref name="Walsh">Walsh T J. ''Second Empire Opera: The Théâtre Lyrique Paris 1851-1870.'' John Calder, London, 1981.</ref>
He was director of the [[Opéra-Comique]] from May 1848 to November 1857, then briefly in 1862, when he 'discovered' [[Galli-Marié]] singing in Rouen.<ref name="Curtiss">Curtiss M. ''Bizet and his world.'' New York, Vienna House, 1974.</ref> From July 1854 to September 1855 he was concurrently director of the [[Théâtre Lyrique]], and during his short tenure the artistic and social standing of the theatre rose, although he resigned, disappointed with the results at the theatre. Wagner described him around this time as "a well-to-do bel esprit and painter".<ref name="Walsh"/>
He became director of the [[Opéra national de Paris|Opéra de Paris]] in December 1862. During this time he employed [[Bizet]] to play through scores submitted to the Opéra, although Perrin did not assist the composer in getting his work performed there. [[Victorien Sardou]] in a letter described Perrin as "the most volatile, the most capricious, the most changeable of men".<ref name="Dean"/> He was dismissed from the Opéra after being accused of insufficient patriotism in May 1870.<ref name="Curtiss"/>
In 1875, he was brought in to arbitrate in a dispute between Bizet and the directors of the Opéra-Comique over the preparations for ''[[Carmen]]'', despite the fact that he loathed the piece.<ref name="Curtiss"/>
He was administrator-general of the [[Comédie-Française]] from 1871 up to his death. In 1876 he became a member of the [[Académie des beaux-arts (France)|Académie des beaux-arts]].<ref>Gourret J. ''Ces hommes qui ont fait l'Opéra''. Editions Albatros, Paris, 1984.</ref>
